The article has been retracted by both Rolling Stone and Salon but the wikipedia page for it still exists.  [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deadly\_Immunity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deadly_Immunity)  Rolling Stone just wiped the article from the record. Salon issued a formal statement of retraction and reasons they chose to do so:  [https://www.salon.com/2011/01/16/dangerous\_immunity/](https://www.salon.com/2011/01/16/dangerous_immunity/)  In the article, RFK Jr engages in selective science, that is, only mentioning the findings he thinks corroborated his claims while either ignoring the refuting evidence or worse citing it as fraudulent.  Some highlights of the evidence he neglected to or purposefully avoided mentioning:  1. Despite the article coming out in 2005, thimerosal hasn't been put into children's vaccines since 2001: [https://www.cdc.gov/vaccinesafety/concerns/thimerosal/index.html](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccinesafety/concerns/thimerosal/index.html) 2. His piece ignored the Institute of Medicine study from the year prior of which the results specifically contradicted his claims: [https://nap.nationalacademies.org/catalog/10997/immunization-safety-review-vaccines-and-autism](https://nap.nationalacademies.org/catalog/10997/immunization-safety-review-vaccines-and-autism) 3. Additionally, he either ignored or neglected to mention the 9 studies commissioned by the CDC between 2003-2005 of which their findings ALSO directly contradicted his claims: [https://www.cdc.gov/vaccinesafety/pdf/cdcstudiesonvaccinesandautism.pdf](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccinesafety/pdf/cdcstudiesonvaccinesandautism.pdf)  RFK Jr. frequently engages in [availability heuristics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Availability_heuristic). In layman's terms, he uses buzz words and catch phrases to convince people that a claim is true while ignoring the underlying data that often times contradicts the flashy headline.  For example: Here's a clip from his interview with Joe Rogan. His claim is that "Wifi-radiation causes cancer because wifi-radiation opens up your blood-brain barrier."  When simply asked "How does that happen?" he neglects to answer.  [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z-YQ1Y7c\_Pk](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z-YQ1Y7c_Pk)  Notice that he then goes on to say there are "10s of thousands of studies that show this is the case" but fails to cite a single one.  YOU can do a simple Google Search of "Blood Brain Barrier WIFI Study" and see that there are indeed MANY studies of the affects of wifi on animals, and they all contradict his claims.  Here's an example: [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7453585/](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7453585/)  >In conclusion, UWB-EMP exposure increased BBB permeability transiently and safely in a field strength-dependent manner.  Notice how, if taken partially this result could be said to support his claim  >In conclusion, UWB-EMP exposure increased BBB permeability  But in totality does not.  >transiently and safely in a field strength-dependent manner.  That is the type of "scientific discussion" that RFK Jr. engages in. One that lacks nuance, totality, and frankly honesty by speaking in half-truths and treating them as the whole picture.  But lets not stop there, lets take a moment and consider Occam's Razor.  In order for RFK Jrs claims about medical officials the world over knowingly using thimerosal in vaccines while also knowing that it "causes autism" (it does not) to be true, it would involve the cooperation of hundreds of thousands of scientists and doctors from dozens and dozens of countries knowingly altering the experimental outcomes of hundreds of thousands of tests over a hundred years with the intention of misleading the public.  Which sounds more plausible to you? That? Or one man using his family name to propagate conspiracies for his political benefit?
